Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving or placing one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say,
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /

Read the title. Explain that this is a poem with short lines, rhyming words, and descriptive language.
For the first reading, have students echo-read the poem after you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can switch stanzas during the rereadings.

Prompt students to find all the two-syllable words in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask them to identify closed syllables and open syllables. Provide support as needed. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
